44.text:
And now to patient judgments we appeal,

52.text:
Now is he born of parents base of stock,
In Germany, within a town call'd Rhodes:

59.text:
At riper years, to Wittenberg he went,

66.text:
So much he profits in divinity,
That shortly he was grac'd with doctor's name,

73.text:
Excelling all, and sweetly can dispute
In th' heavenly matters of theology;

79.text:
Till swoln with cunning, of a self-conceit,

86.text:
And, melting, heavens conspir'd his overthrow;
For, falling to a devilish exercise,

93.text:
And glutted now with learning's golden gifts,

101.text:
Nothing so sweet as magic is to him,
Which he prefers before his chiefest bliss:

107.text: And this the man that in his study sits.

119.text:
Settle thy studies, Faustus, and begin

133.text:

141.text:
Bene disserere est finis logices.

end:

Summum bonum medicinoe sanitas,

178.text:

186.text:
end?

For four-and-twenty years to breathe on earth?
And, had you cut my body with your swords,

5497.text:
Or hew'd this flesh and bones as small as
sand,

5502.text:
Yet in a minute had my spirit return'd,
And I had breath'd a man, made free from harm.

5509.text:
But wherefore do I dally my revenge?—
Asteroth, Belimoth, Mephistophilis?

5521.text:
Go, horse these traitors on your fiery backs,
And mount aloft with them as high as heaven:

5529.text:
Thence pitch them headlong to the lowest hell.
Yet, stay: the world shall see their misery,

5538.text:
And hell shall after plague their treachery.
Go, Belimoth, and take this caitiff hence,

5546.text:
And hurl him in some lake of mud and dirt.
Take thou this other, drag him through the

5552.text:
woods
Amongst the pricking thorns and sharpest briers;

5556.text:
Whilst, with my gentle Mephistophilis,
This traitor flies unto some steepy rock,

5562.text:
That, rolling down, may break the villain's
bones,

5565.text:
As he intended to dismember me.
Fly hence; despatch my charge immediately.

5572.text: Pity us, gentle Faustus! save our lives!

5577.text:
He must needs go that the devil drives.
[Exeunt MEPHISTOPHILIS and DEVILS with BENVOLIO,

5588.text:
Come, sirs, prepare yourselves in readiness;
Make haste to help these noble gentlemen:

5594.text: I heard them parley with the conjurer.

5596.text:
See, where he comes! despatch and kill the
slave.

5602.text:
What's here? an ambush to betray my life!
Then, Faustus, try thy skill.—Base peasants,

5610.text:
stand!
For, lo, these trees remove at my command,

5619.text:
And stand as bulwarks 'twixt yourselves and
me,

5622.text:
To shield me from your hated treachery!
Yet, to encounter this your weak attempt,

5632.text:
FAUSTUS strikes the door, and enter a DEVIL
playing

5636.text:
on a drum; after him another, bearing an ensign;
and divers

5640.text:
with weapons; MEPHISTOPHILIS with fire-works.
They set upon

5645.text: the SOLDIERS, drive them out, and exeunt.

5648.text:
Enter, at several doors, BENVOLIO, FREDERICK,
and MARTINO,

5653.text:
their heads and faces bloody, and besmeared
with mud and

5657.text: dirt; all having horns on their heads.

5665.text: O, help me, gentle friend!—Where is Martino?

5670.text:
Dear Frederick, here,
Half smother'd in a lake of mud and dirt,

5677.text:
Through which the Furies dragg'd me by the
heels.

5689.text: Defend me, heaven! shall I be haunted still?

5694.text: Nay, fear not, man; we have no power to kill.

5699.text:
My friends transformed thus! O, hellish spite!
Your heads are all set with horns.

5709.text:
You hit it right;
It is your own you mean; feel on your head.

5716.text: Nay, chafe not, man; we all are sped.

5722.text:
What devil attends this damn'd magician,
That, spite of spite, our wrongs are doubled?

5729.text: What may we do, that we may hide our shames?

5733.text:
If we should follow him to work revenge,
He'd join long asses' ears to these huge horns,

5741.text: And make us laughing-stocks to all the world.

5745.text: What shall we, then, do, dear Benvolio?

5749.text:
I have a castle joining near these woods;
And thither we'll repair, and live obscure,

5756.text:
Till time shall alter these our brutish shapes:
Sith black disgrace hath thus eclips'd our

5765.text:
fame,
We'll rather die with grief than live with

5774.text: Enter FAUSTUS, a HORSE-COURSER, and MEPHISTOPHILIS.

5779.text:
I beseech your worship, accept of these forty
dollars.

5783.text:
Friend, thou canst not buy so good a horse
for so small a price. I have no great need

5791.text:
to sell him: but, if thou likest him for ten
dollars more, take him, because I see thou

5797.text: hast a good mind to him.

5799.text:
I beseech you, sir, accept of this: I am a
very poor man, and have lost very much of

5805.text:
late by horse-flesh, and this bargain will
set me up again.

5808.text:
Well, I will not stand with thee: give me
the money [HORSE-COURSER gives FAUSTUS the

5815.text:
money]. Now, sirrah, I must tell you that
you may ride him o'er hedge and ditch, and

5822.text:
spare him not; but, do you hear? in any case,
ride him not into the water.

5828.text:
How, sir! not into the water! why, will he
not drink of all waters?

5834.text:
Yes, he will drink of all waters; but ride
him not into the water: o'er hedge and ditch,

5841.text:
or where thou wilt, but not into the water.
Go, bid the hostler deliver him unto you,

5849.text:
I warrant you, sir!—O, joyful day! now am
I a made man for ever.

5857.text:
What art thou, Faustus, but a man condemn'd
to die?

5862.text:
Thy fatal time draws to a final end;
Despair doth drive distrust into my thoughts:

5871.text:
Confound these passions with a quiet sleep:
Tush, Christ did call the thief upon the Cross;

5879.text:
Then rest thee, Faustus, quiet in conceit.
[He sits to sleep.]

5887.text:
O, what a cozening doctor was this! I, riding
my horse into the water, thinking some hidden

5894.text:
mystery had been in the horse, I had nothing
under me but a little straw, and had much

5899.text:
ado to escape drowning. Well, I'll go rouse
him, and make him give me my forty dollars

5905.text:
again.—Ho, sirrah Doctor, you cozening scab!
Master Doctor, awake, and rise, and give me

5912.text:
my money again, for your horse is turned to
a bottle of hay, Master Doctor! [He pulls

5917.text:
off FAUSTUS' leg]. Alas, I am undone! What
shall I do? I have pulled off his leg.

5925.text: O, help, help! the villain hath murdered me.

5930.text:
Murder or not murder, now he has but one leg,
I'll outrun him, and cast this leg into some

5936.text:
ditch or other.
[Aside, and then runs out.]

5940.text:
Stop him, stop him, stop him!—Ha, ha, ha!
Faustus hath his leg again, and the Horse-courser

5950.text: a bundle of hay for his forty dollars.

5957.text: How now, Wagner! what news with thee?

5960.text:
If it please you, the Duke of Vanholt doth
earnestly entreat your company, and hath sent

5966.text:
some of his men to attend you, with provision
fit for your journey.

5971.text:
The Duke of Vanholt's an honourable gentleman,
and one to whom I must be no niggard of my

5984.text:
Enter ROBIN, DICK, the HORSE-COURSER, and
a

5987.text:
Come, my masters, I'll bring you to the best
beer in Europe.—What, ho, hostess! where

5997.text:
How now! what lack you? What, my old guess!
welcome.

6001.text:
Sirrah Dick, dost thou know why I stand so
mute?

6007.text:
I am eighteen-pence on the score. but say
nothing; see if she have forgotten me.

6013.text:
Who's this that stands so solemnly by himself?
What, my old guest!

6017.text:
O, hostess, how do you? I hope my score stands
still.

6023.text:
Ay, there's no doubt of that; for methinks
you make no haste to wipe it out.

6028.text: Why, hostess, I say, fetch us some beer.

6032.text:
You shall presently.—Look up into the hall
there, ho!

6040.text:
Come, sirs, what shall we do now till mine
hostess comes?

6044.text:
Marry, sir, I'll tell you the bravest tale
how a conjurer served me. You know Doctor

6051.text:
Ay, a plague take him! here's some on's have
cause to know him. Did he conjure thee too?

6058.text:
I'll tell you how he served me. As I was going
to Wittenberg, t'other day, with a load of

6062.text:
hay, he met me, and asked me what he should
give me for as much hay as he could eat. Now,

6067.text:
sir, I thinking that a little would serve
his turn, bad him take as much as he would

6072.text:
for three farthings: so he presently gave
me my money and fell to eating; and, as I

6078.text:
am a cursen man, he never left eating till
he had eat up all my load of hay.

6083.text: O, monstrous! eat a whole load of hay!

6088.text:
Yes, yes, that may be; for I have heard of
one that has eat a load of logs.

6093.text:
Now, sirs, you shall hear how villanously
he

6096.text:
served me. I went to him yesterday to buy
a horse of him, and

6100.text:
he would by no means sell him under forty
dollars. So, sir,

6105.text:
because I knew him to be such a horse as would
run over hedge and ditch and never tire, I

6109.text:
gave him his money. So, when I had my horse,
Doctor Faustus bad me ride him night and day,

6115.text:
and spare him no time; but, quoth he, in any
case, ride him not into the water. Now, sir,

6123.text:
I thinking the horse had had some quality
that he would not have me know of, what did

6127.text:
I but rid him into a great river? and when
I came just in the midst, my horse vanished

6133.text:
away, and I sate straddling upon a bottle
of hay.

6140.text:
But you shall hear how bravely I served him
for it. I went me home to his house, and there

6145.text:
I found him asleep. I kept a hallooing and
whooping in his ears; but all could not wake

6151.text:
him. I, seeing that, took him by the leg,
and never rested pulling till I had pulled

6156.text:
me his leg quite off; and now 'tis at home
in mine hostry.

6160.text:
And has the doctor but one leg, then? that's
excellent; for one of his devils turned me

6165.text: into the likeness of an ape's face.

6169.text:
Hark you, we'll into another room and drink
a while, and then we'll go seek out the doctor.

6178.text:
Enter the DUKE OF VANHOLT, his DUCHESS, FAUSTUS,
MEPHISTOPHILIS, and ATTENDANTS.

6185.text:
Thanks, Master Doctor, for these pleasant
sights; nor know I how sufficiently to recompense

6191.text:
your great deserts in erecting that enchanted
castle in the air, the sight whereof so delighted

6198.text:
me as nothing in the world could please me
more.

6202.text:
I do think myself, my good lord, highly recompensed
in that it pleaseth your grace to think but

6210.text:
well of that which Faustus hath performed.—But,
gracious lady, it may be that you have taken

6217.text:
no pleasure in those sights; therefore, I
pray you tell me, what is the thing you most

6224.text:
desire to have; be it in the world, it shall
be yours: I have heard that great-bellied

6230.text: women do long for things are rare and dainty.

6234.text:
True, Master Doctor; and, since I find you
so kind, I will make known unto you what my

6240.text:
heart desires to have; and, were it now summer,
as it is January, a dead time of the winter,

6248.text:
I would request no better meat than a dish
of ripe grapes.

6254.text:
This is but a small matter.—Go, Mephistophilis;
away!

6258.text:
[Exit MEPHISTOPHILIS.]
Madam, I will do more than this for your content.

6268.text:
Here now, taste you these: they should be
good, for they come from a far country, I

6275.text:
This makes me wonder more than all the rest,
that at this time of the year, when every

6281.text:
tree is barren of his fruit, from whence you
had these ripe grapes.

6287.text:
Please it your grace, the year is divided
into two circles over the whole world; so

6293.text:
that, when it is winter with us, in the contrary
circle it is likewise summer with them, as

6299.text:
in India, Saba, and such countries that lie
far east, where they have fruit twice a-year;

6305.text:
from whence, by means of a swift spirit that
I have, I had these grapes brought, as you

6311.text:
And, trust me, they are the sweetest grapes
that e'er I tasted.

6318.text: The CLOWNS bounce at the gate, within.

6321.text:
What rude disturbers have we at the gate?
Go, pacify their fury, set it ope,

6329.text: And then demand of them what they would have.

6331.text:
[They knock again, and call out to talk with
FAUSTUS.]

6335.text:
Why, how now, masters! what a coil is there!
What is the reason you disturb the Duke?

6343.text:
DICK [within]. We have no reason for it; therefore
a fig for him!

6349.text: Why, saucy varlets, dare you be so bold?

6354.text:
HORSE-COURSER [within]. I hope, sir, we have
wit enough to be

6359.text:
It appears so: pray, be bold elsewhere, and
trouble not the Duke.

6367.text: They all cry out to speak with Doctor Faustus.

6372.text:
CARTER [within]. Ay, and we will speak with
him.

6379.text:
DICK [within]. Commit with us! he were as
good commit with his father as commit with

6387.text:
I do beseech your grace, let them come in;
They are good subject for a merriment.

6394.text: Do as thou wilt, Faustus; I give thee leave.

6400.text: Enter ROBIN, DICK, CARTER, and HORSE-COURSER.

6404.text:
Why, how now, my good friends!
Faith, you are too outrageous: but, come near;

6412.text: I have procur'd your pardons: welcome, all.

6415.text:
Nay, sir, we will be welcome for our money,
and we will pay for what we take.—What,

6420.text:
ho! give's half a dozen of beer here, and
be hanged!

6424.text: Nay, hark you; can you tell me where you are?

6428.text: Ay, marry, can I; we are under heaven.

6433.text: Ay; but, Sir Saucebox, know you in what place?

6437.text:
Ay, ay, the house is good enough to drink
in.

6440.text:
—Zouns, fill us some beer, or we'll break
all the barrels in

6443.text:
the house, and dash out all your brains with
your bottles!

6447.text:
Be not so furious: come, you shall have beer.—
My lord, beseech you give me leave a while;

6456.text: I'll gage my credit 'twill content your grace.

6460.text:
With all my heart, kind doctor; please thyself;
Our servants and our court's at thy command.

6467.text:
I humbly thank your grace.—Then fetch some
beer.

6471.text:
Ay, marry, there spake a doctor, indeed!
and, faith, I'll drink a health to thy wooden

6479.text: My wooden leg! what dost thou mean by that?

6483.text:
Ha, ha, ha!—Dost hear him, Dick? he has
forgot his leg.

6489.text: Ay, ay, he does not stand much upon that.

6492.text: No, faith; not much upon a wooden leg.

6497.text:
Good Lord, that flesh and blood should be
so frail with your worship! Do not you remember

6502.text: a horse-courser you sold a horse to?

6505.text: Yes, I remember I sold one a horse.

6508.text:
And do you remember you bid he should not
ride him into the water?

6512.text: Yes, I do very well remember that.

6515.text: And do you remember nothing of your leg?

6520.text: Then, I pray you, remember your courtesy.

6526.text:
'Tis not so much worth. I pray you, tell me
one thing.

6531.text:
Be both your legs bed-fellows every night
together?

6535.text:
Wouldst thou make a Colossus of me, that thou
askest me such questions?

6540.text:
No, truly, sir; I would make nothing of you;
but I would fain know that.

6547.text: Then, I assure thee certainly, they are.

6552.text: I thank you; I am fully satisfied.

6557.text:
For nothing, sir: but methinks you should
have a wooden bed-fellow of one of 'em.

6562.text:
Why, do you hear, sir? did not I pull off
one of your legs when you were asleep?

6568.text:
But I have it again, now I am awake: look
you here, sir.

6573.text: O, horrible! had the doctor three legs?

6577.text:
Do you remember, sir, how you cozened me,
and eat up my

6582.text:
[FAUSTUS, in the middle of each speech, charms
them dumb.]

6586.text: Do you remember how you made me wear an ape's——

6589.text:
You whoreson conjuring scab, do you remember
how you cozened me with a ho——

6595.text:
Ha' you forgotten me? you think to carry it
away with your hey-pass and re-pass: do you

6605.text:
Who pays for the ale? hear you, Master Doctor;
now you have sent away my guess, I pray who

6611.text:
shall pay me for my a——
[Exit HOSTESS.]

6616.text:
My lord,
We are much beholding to this learned man.

6620.text:
So are we, madam; which we will recompense
With all the love and kindness that we may:

6628.text:
His artful sport drives all sad thoughts away.
[Exeunt.]

6636.text:
End of Act IV
Act V, Scene I

6644.text:
Thunder and lightning. Enter DEVILS with covered
dishes;

6649.text:
MEPHISTOPHILIS leads them into FAUSTUS'S study;
then enter

6653.text:
I think my master means to die shortly; he
has made his will, and given me his wealth,

6663.text:
his house, his goods, and store of golden
plate, besides two thousand ducats ready-coined.

6671.text:
I wonder what he means: if death were nigh,
he would not frolic thus. He's now at supper

6681.text:
with the scholars, where there's such belly-cheer
as Wagner in his life ne'er saw the like:

6688.text:
and, see where they come! belike the feast
is ended.

6693.text:
Enter FAUSTUS, MEPHISTOPHILIS, and two or
three SCHOLARS.

6701.text:
Master Doctor Faustus, since our conference
about fair ladies, which was the beautifulest

6705.text:
in all the world, we have determined with
ourselves that Helen of Greece was the admirablest

6710.text:
lady that ever lived: therefore, Master Doctor,
if you will do us so much favour as to let

6716.text:
us see that peerless dame of Greece, whom
all the world admires for majesty, we should

6722.text: think ourselves much beholding unto you.

6725.text:
Gentlemen,
For that I know your friendship is unfeign'd,

6729.text:
It is not Faustus' custom to deny
The just request of those that wish him well:

6735.text:
You shall behold that peerless dame of Greece,
No otherwise for pomp or majesty

6740.text:
Than when Sir Paris cross'd the seas with
her,

6743.text:
And brought the spoils to rich Dardania.
Be silent, then, for danger is in words.

6750.text:
Music sounds. MEPHISTOPHILIS brings in HELEN;
she passeth

6756.text:
Was this fair Helen, whose admired worth
Made Greece with ten years' war afflict poor

6764.text:
Too simple is my wit to tell her worth,
Whom all the world admires for majesty.

6771.text:
Now we have seen the pride of Nature's work,
We'll take our leaves: and, for this blessed

6776.text:
sight,
Happy and blest be Faustus evermore!

6780.text:
Gentlemen, farewell: the same wish I to you.
[Exeunt SCHOLARS.]

6789.text:
O gentle Faustus, leave this damned art,
This magic, that will charm thy soul to hell,

6799.text:
And quite bereave thee of salvation!
Though thou hast now offended like a man,

6805.text:
Do not persever in it like a devil:
Yet, yet thou hast an amiable soul,

6813.text:
If sin by custom grow not into nature;
Then, Faustus, will repentance come too late;

6821.text:
Then thou art banish'd from the sight of heaven:
No mortal can express the pains of hell.

6829.text:
It may be, this my exhortation
Seems harsh and all unpleasant: let it not;

6836.text:
For, gentle son, I speak it not in wrath,
Or envy of thee, but in tender love,

6845.text:
And pity of thy future misery;
And so have hope that this my kind rebuke,

6853.text: Checking thy body, may amend thy soul.

6857.text:
Where art thou, Faustus? wretch, what hast
thou done?

6865.text:
Hell claims his right, and with a roaring
voice

6868.text:
Says, "Faustus, come; thine hour is almost
come;"

6874.text: And Faustus now will come to do thee right.

6881.text:
O, stay, good Faustus, stay thy desperate
steps!

6884.text:
I see an angel hover o'er thy head,
And, with a vial full of precious grace,

6894.text:
Offers to pour the same into thy soul:
Then call for mercy, and avoid despair.

6901.text:
O friend, I feel
Thy words to comfort my distressed soul!

6908.text: Leave me a while to ponder on my sins.

6911.text:
Faustus, I leave thee; but with grief of heart,
Fearing the enemy of thy hapless soul.

6921.text:
Accursed Faustus, wretch, what hast thou done?
I do repent; and yet I do despair:

6935.text:
Hell strives with grace for conquest in my
breast:

6941.text: What shall I do to shun the snares of death?

6946.text:
Thou traitor, Faustus, I arrest thy soul
For disobedience to my sovereign lord:

6952.text: Revolt, or I'll in piece-meal tear thy flesh.

6958.text:
I do repent I e'er offended him.
Sweet Mephistophilis, entreat thy lord

6964.text:
To pardon my unjust presumption,
And with my blood again I will confirm

6968.text: The former vow I made to Lucifer.

6971.text:
Do it, then, Faustus, with unfeigned heart,
Lest greater dangers do attend thy drift.

6979.text:
Torment, sweet friend, that base and aged
man,

6983.text:
That durst dissuade me from thy Lucifer,
With greatest torments that our hell affords.

6990.text:
His faith is great; I cannot touch his soul;
But what I may afflict his body with

6996.text: I will attempt, which is but little worth.

7000.text:
One thing, good servant, let me crave of thee,
To glut the longing of my heart's desire,—

7007.text:
That I may have unto my paramour
That heavenly Helen which I saw of late,

7013.text:
Whose sweet embraces may extinguish clean
Those thoughts that do dissuade me from my

7018.text:
vow,
And keep my oath I made to Lucifer.

7021.text:
This, or what else my Faustus shall desire,
Shall be perform'd in twinkling of an eye.

7029.text:
Re-enter HELEN, passing over the stage between
two CUPIDS.

7033.text:
Was this the face that launch'd a thousand
ships,

7040.text:
And burnt the topless towers of Ilium?—
Sweet Helen, make me immortal with a kiss.—

7050.text:
[Kisses her.]
Her lips suck forth my soul: see, where it

7056.text:
flies!—
Come, Helen, come, give me my soul again.

7062.text:
Here will I dwell, for heaven is in these
lips,

7066.text:
And all is dross that is not Helena.
I will be Paris, and for love of thee,

7073.text:
Instead of Troy, shall Wittenberg be sack'd;
And I will combat with weak Menelaus,

7078.text:
And wear thy colours on my plumed crest;
Yea, I will wound Achilles in the heel,

7085.text:
And then return to Helen for a kiss.
O, thou art fairer than the evening air

7092.text:
Clad in the beauty of a thousand stars;
Brighter art thou than flaming Jupiter

7100.text:
When he appear'd to hapless Semele;
More lovely than the monarch of the sky

7105.text:
In wanton Arethusa's azur'd arms;
And none but thou shalt be my paramour!

7113.text: Thunder. Enter LUCIFER, BELZEBUB, and MEPHISTOPHILIS.

7116.text:
Thus from infernal Dis do we ascend
To view the subjects of our monarchy,

7130.text:
Those souls which sin seals the black sons
of hell;

7135.text:
'Mong which, as chief, Faustus, we come to
thee,

7141.text:
Bringing with us lasting damnation
To wait upon thy soul: the time is come

7151.text:
And, this gloomy night,
Here, in this room, will wretched Faustus

7158.text:
And here we'll stay,
To mark him how he doth demean himself.

7162.text:
How should he but in desperate lunacy?
Fond worldling, now his heart-blood dries

7169.text:
with grief;
His conscience kills it; and his labouring

7173.text:
brain
Begets a world of idle fantasies

7176.text:
To over-reach the devil; but all in vain;
His store of pleasures must be sauc'd with

7183.text:
pain.
He and his servant Wagner are at hand;

7187.text:
Both come from drawing Faustus' latest will.
See, where they come!

7194.text:
Say, Wagner,—thou hast perus'd my will,—
How dost thou like it?

7200.text:
Sir, So wondrous well,
As in all humble duty I do yield

7206.text: My life and lasting service for your love.

7215.text:
Now, worthy Faustus, methinks your looks are
chang'd.

7225.text:
Ah, my sweet chamber-fellow, had I lived with
thee,

7229.text:
then had I lived still! but now must die eternally.
Look, sirs,

7235.text: comes he not? comes he not?

7237.text: O my dear Faustus, what imports this fear?

7241.text: Is all our pleasure turn'd to melancholy?

7244.text: He is not well with being over-solitary.

7245.text:
If it be so, we'll have physicians,
And Faustus shall be cur'd.

7252.text: 'Tis but a surfeit, sir; fear nothing.

7255.text:
A surfeit of deadly sin, that hath damned
both body and soul.

7260.text:
Yet, Faustus, look up to heaven, and remember
mercy is infinite.

7266.text:
But Faustus' offence can ne'er be pardoned:
the serpent that tempted Eve may be saved,

7272.text:
but not O gentlemen, hear me with patience,
and tremble not at my speeches! Though my

7280.text:
heart pant and quiver to remember that I have
been a student here these thirty years, O,

7287.text:
would I had never seen Wittenberg, never read
book! and what wonders I have done, all Germany

7293.text:
can witness, yea, all the world; for which
Faustus hath lost both Germany and the world,

7301.text:
yea, heaven itself, heaven, the seat of God,
the throne of the blessed, the kingdom of

7307.text:
joy; and must remain in hell for ever, hell.
O, hell, for ever! Sweet friends,

7323.text:
On God, whom Faustus hath abjured! on God,
whom Faustus hath blasphemed! O my God, I

7333.text:
would weep! but the devil draws in my tears.
Gush forth blood, instead of tears! yea, life

7341.text:
and soul! O, he stays my tongue! I would lift
up my hands; but see, they hold 'em, they

7352.text:
Why, Lucifer and Mephistophilis. O gentlemen,
I gave them my soul for my cunning!

7361.text:
God forbade it, indeed; but Faustus hath done
it: for the vain pleasure of four-and-twenty

7368.text:
years hath Faustus lost eternal joy and felicity.
I writ them a bill with mine own blood: the

7377.text:
date is expired; this is the time, and he
will fetch me.

7380.text:
Why did not Faustus tell us of this before,
that divines might have prayed for thee?

7386.text:
Oft have I thought to have done so; but the
devil threatened to tear me in pieces, if

7391.text:
I named God, to fetch me body and soul, if
I once gave ear to divinity: and now 'tis

7398.text:
too late. Gentlemen, away, lest you perish
with me.

7404.text: O, what may we do to save Faustus?

7408.text: Talk not of me, but save yourselves, and depart.

7412.text: God will strengthen me; I will stay with Faustus.

7415.text:
Tempt not God, sweet friend; but let us into
the

7418.text: next room, and pray for him.

7421.text:
Ay, pray for me, pray for me; and what noise
soever you hear, come not unto me, for nothing

7432.text:
Pray thou, and we will pray that God may have
mercy upon thee.

7437.text:
Gentlemen, farewell: if I live till morning,
I'll visit you; if not, Faustus is gone to

7449.text:
Ay, Faustus, now thou hast no hope of heaven;
Therefore despair; think only upon hell,

7458.text: For that must be thy mansion, there to dwell.

7462.text:
O thou bewitching fiend, 'twas thy temptation
Hath robb'd me of eternal happiness!

7469.text:
I do confess it, Faustus, and rejoice:
'Twas I that, when thou wert i'the way to

7477.text:
heaven,
Damm'd up thy passage; when thou took'st the

7480.text:
book
To view the Scriptures, then I turn'd the

7487.text:
What, weep'st thou? 'tis too late; despair!
Farewell:

7492.text:
Fools that will laugh on earth must weep in
hell.

7501.text:
Enter GOOD ANGEL and EVIL ANGEL at several
doors.

7504.text:
O Faustus, if thou hadst given ear to me,
Innumerable joys had follow'd thee!

7511.text: But thou didst love the world.

7513.text:
Gave ear to me,
And now must taste hell-pains perpetually.

7519.text:
O, what will all thy riches, pleasures, pomps,
Avail thee now?

7525.text:
Nothing, but vex thee more,
To want in hell, that had on earth such store.

7534.text:
O, thou hast lost celestial happiness,
Pleasures unspeakable, bliss without end

7541.text:
Hadst thou affected sweet divinity,
Hell or the devil had had no power on thee:

7547.text:
Hadst thou kept on that way, Faustus, behold,
[Music, while a throne descends.]

7554.text:
In what resplendent glory thou hadst sit
In yonder throne, like those bright-shining

7560.text:
saints,
And triumph'd over hell! That hast thou lost;

7565.text:
And now, poor soul, must thy good angel leave
thee:

7568.text:
The jaws of hell are open to receive thee.
[Exit. The throne ascends.]

7575.text:
Now, Faustus, let thine eyes with horror stare
[Hell is discovered.]

7584.text:
Into that vast perpetual torture-house:
There are the Furies tossing damned souls

7592.text:
On burning forks; there bodies boil in lead;
There are live quarters broiling on the coals,

7604.text:
That ne'er can die; this ever-burning chair
Is for o'er-tortur'd souls to rest them in;

7613.text:
These that are fed with sops of flaming fire,
Were gluttons, and lov'd only delicates,

7621.text:
And laugh'd to see the poor starve at their
gates:

7626.text:
But yet all these are nothing; thou shalt
see

7631.text: Ten thousand tortures that more horrid be.

7636.text: O, I have seen enough to torture me!

7641.text:
Nay, thou must feel them, taste the smart
of all:

7648.text:
He that loves pleasure must for pleasure fall:
And so I leave thee, Faustus, till anon;

7657.text:
Then wilt thou tumble in confusion.
[Exit. Hell disappears.—The clock strikes

7667.text:
O Faustus,
Now hast thou but one bare hour to live,

7673.text:
And then thou must be damn'd perpetually!
Stand still, you ever-moving spheres of heaven,

7680.text:
That time may cease, and midnight never come;
Fair Nature's eye, rise, rise again, and make

7687.text:
Perpetual day; or let this hour be but
A year, a month, a week, a natural day,

7696.text:
That Faustus may repent and save his soul!
O lente, lente currite, noctis equi!

7708.text:
The stars move still, time runs, the clock
will strike,

7714.text:
The devil will come, and Faustus must be damn'd.
O, I'll leap up to heaven!—Who pulls me

7723.text:
down?—
See, where Christ's blood streams in the firmament!

7728.text:
One drop of blood will save me: O my Christ!—
Rend not my heart for naming of my Christ;

7737.text:
Yet will I call on him: O, spare me, Lucifer!—
Where is it now? 'tis gone:

7744.text:
And, see, a threatening arm, an angry brow!
Mountains and hills, come, come, and fall

7752.text:
on me,
And hide me from the heavy wrath of heaven!

7755.text:
No!
Then will I headlong run into the earth:

7759.text:
Gape, earth! O, no, it will not harbour me!
You stars that reign'd at my nativity,

7767.text:
Whose influence hath allotted death and hell,
Now draw up Faustus, like a foggy mist,

7773.text:
Into the entrails of yon labouring cloud[s],
That, when you vomit forth into the air,

7778.text:
My limbs may issue from your smoky mouths;
But let my soul mount and ascend to heaven!

7785.text:
[The clock strikes the half-hour.]
O, half the hour is past! 'twill all be past

7793.text:
anon.
O, if my soul must suffer for my sin,

7799.text:
Impose some end to my incessant pain;
Let Faustus live in hell a thousand years,

7806.text:
A hundred thousand, and at last be sav'd!
No end is limited to damned souls.

7815.text:
Why wert thou not a creature wanting soul?
Or why is this immortal that thou hast?

7822.text:
O, Pythagoras' metempsychosis, were that true,
This soul should fly from me, and I be chang'd

7829.text:
Into some brutish beast! all beasts are happy,
For, when they die,

7833.text:
Their souls are soon dissolv'd in elements;
But mine must live still to be plagu'd in

7840.text:
hell.
Curs'd be the parents that engender'd me!

7845.text:
No, Faustus, curse thyself, curse Lucifer
That hath depriv'd thee of the joys of heaven.

7852.text:
[The clock strikes twelve.]
It strikes, it strikes! Now, body, turn to

7860.text:
air,
Or Lucifer will bear thee quick to hell!

7863.text:
O soul, be chang'd into small water-drops,
And fall into the ocean, ne'er be found!

7872.text:
O, mercy, heaven! look not so fierce on me!
Adders and serpents, let me breathe a while!

7881.text:
Ugly hell, gape not! come not, Lucifer!
I'll burn my books!—O Mephistophilis!

7898.text:
Come, gentlemen, let us go visit Faustus,
For such a dreadful night was never seen;

7905.text:
Since first the world's creation did begin,
Such fearful shrieks and cries were never

7910.text:
heard:
Pray heaven the doctor have escap'd the danger.

7914.text:
O, help us, heaven! see, here are Faustus'
limbs,

7918.text: All torn asunder by the hand of death!

7921.text:
The devils whom Faustus serv'd have torn him
thus;

7925.text:
For, twixt the hours of twelve and one, methought,
I heard him shriek and call aloud for help;

7931.text:
At which self time the house seem'd all on
fire

7934.text: With dreadful horror of these damned fiends.

7938.text:
Well, gentlemen, though Faustus' end be such
As every Christian heart laments to think

7944.text:
on,
Yet, for he was a scholar once admir'd

7948.text:
For wondrous knowledge in our German schools,
We'll give his mangled limbs due burial;

7953.text:
And all the students, cloth'd in mourning
black,

7956.text:
Shall wait upon his heavy funeral.
[Exeunt.]

7963.text:
Cut is the branch that might have grown full
straight,

7970.text:
And burned is Apollo's laurel-bough,
That sometime grew within this learned man.

7976.text:
Faustus is gone: regard his hellish fall,
Whose fiendful fortune may exhort the wise,

7984.text:
Only to wonder at unlawful things,
Whose deepness doth entice such forward wits

7991.text:
To practise more than heavenly power permits.
[Exit]

7996.text: Terminat hora diem; terminat auctor opus.

8003.text:
End of Act V
End of The Tragical History of Doctor Faustus

From The Quarto Of 1616
